name: Breaking the Hays Code
description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

key_work.title: From scandal to censorship
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: Concerned that movies promoted loose morals, and scandalised by tabloid stories of stars behaving badly, religious and civic groups lobbied the studios to clean up their act. To avoid government censorship, the industry responded with the Motion Picture Production Code.

constellations_primary.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_primary.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

start.title: The World Moves On
start.creator_credit: John Ford, Fox Film Corporation and Reginald Berkeley
start.brief_description: Two families, cotton merchants in England and America, with branches in France and Prussia swear to stand by each other in a belief that a great business firmly established in four countries will be able to withstand even such another calamity as the Napoleonic Wars from which Europe is slowly recovering. Then many years later, along comes World War One and the years that follow, to test the businesses.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

end.title: To Have and Have Not
end.creator_credit: Howard Hawks, Milo Anderson, Christian Nyby, Warner Bros. Pictures, Jules Furthman, Whitman Chambers and William Faulkner
end.brief_description: A Martinique charter boat skipper gets mixed up with the underground French resistance operatives during WWII.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: With the code restricting what could be shown, filmmakers began to rely on innuendo to illustrate lust and passion. Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart’s famous whistling scene oozes sexual chemistry with Bacall’s silver-tongued banter.

start.title: Red-Headed Woman
start.creator_credit: Jack Conway, Adrian, Blanche Sewell, Albert Lewin, Irving Thalberg, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Anita Loos
start.brief_description: Lil works for the Legendre Company and causes Bill to divorce Irene and marry her. She has an affair with businessman Gaerste and uses him to force society to pay attention to her.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

end.title: The World Moves On
end.creator_credit: John Ford, Fox Film Corporation and Reginald Berkeley
end.brief_description: Two families, cotton merchants in England and America, with branches in France and Prussia swear to stand by each other in a belief that a great business firmly established in four countries will be able to withstand even such another calamity as the Napoleonic Wars from which Europe is slowly recovering. Then many years later, along comes World War One and the years that follow, to test the businesses.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: A love story set against the backdrop of war and the Great Depression, The World Moves On was the first film to receive the official production seal of approval under the Hays Code (MPPDA Certificate No. 1) in November 1934.

start.title: The Outlaw
start.creator_credit: Howard Hughes, Wallace Grissell, Howard Hughes Productions, RKO Radio Pictures and Jules Furthman
start.brief_description: Newly appointed sheriff Pat Garrett is pleased when his old friend Doc Holliday arrives in Lincoln, New Mexico on the stage. Doc is trailing his stolen horse, and it is discovered in the possession of Billy the Kid. In a surprising turnaround, Billy and Doc become friends. This causes the friendship between Doc and Pat to cool. The odd relationship between Doc and Billy grows stranger when Doc hides Billy at his girl Rio’s place after Billy is shot.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

end.title: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?
end.creator_credit: Mike Nichols, Irene Sharaff, Ernest Lehman, Hal W. Polaire, T.J. Healy II, Chenault Productions, Warner Bros. Pictures, Richard Sylbert and Edward Albee
end.brief_description: A bitter, aging couple, with the help of alcohol, use a young couple to fuel anguish and emotional pain towards each other.

constellations_other.name: My People
constellations_other.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, 'My People' was one of the biggest hits of 2007 and propelled by the engaging music video.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: By the 1960s the production code’s decline was in earnest with Warner Bros. Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf the first film to receive a ‘Suggested for Mature Audiences’ label. New Motion Picture Production Association President Jack Valenti introduced the Film Rating System in November 1968.

start.title: To Have and Have Not
start.creator_credit: Howard Hawks, Milo Anderson, Christian Nyby, Warner Bros. Pictures, Jules Furthman, Whitman Chambers and William Faulkner
start.brief_description: A Martinique charter boat skipper gets mixed up with the underground French resistance operatives during WWII.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

end.title: The Maltese Falcon
end.brief_description: A lovely dame with dangerous lies employs the services of a private detective, who is quickly caught up in the mystery and intrigue of a statuette known as the Maltese Falcon.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: Bogart would redefine his career and create an all new style of shady hero in The Maltese Falcon, considered by many to be the first noir film. Bogart’s detective would be wooed by duplicitous femme fatales yet get by with his wits and ability to hide in the shadows.

start.title: The Maltese Falcon
start.brief_description: A lovely dame with dangerous lies employs the services of a private detective, who is quickly caught up in the mystery and intrigue of a statuette known as the Maltese Falcon.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

end.title: Hotel Dusk: Room 215
end.brief_description: Take control of an interactive mystery novel and discover the secrets of Hotel Dusk. Who is Kyle Hyde- and what really happened in Room 215? Take stylus in hand and navigate a tangled web of lies, betrayal, and murder to learn the answers.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: With an illustrative black and white design, dynamic lighting and camera angles, classic noir-esque dialogue and charismatic flawed hero, Nintendo’s Hotel Dusk: Room 215 was clearly inspired by film noir using the genre to great effect in its point and click adventure game.

start.title: To Have and Have Not
start.creator_credit: Howard Hawks, Milo Anderson, Christian Nyby, Warner Bros. Pictures, Jules Furthman, Whitman Chambers and William Faulkner
start.brief_description: A Martinique charter boat skipper gets mixed up with the underground French resistance operatives during WWII.

Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

end.title: The Outlaw
end.creator_credit: Howard Hughes, Wallace Grissell, Howard Hughes Productions, RKO Radio Pictures and Jules Furthman
end.brief_description: Newly appointed sheriff Pat Garrett is pleased when his old friend Doc Holliday arrives in Lincoln, New Mexico on the stage. Doc is trailing his stolen horse, and it is discovered in the possession of Billy the Kid. In a surprising turnaround, Billy and Doc become friends. This causes the friendship between Doc and Pat to cool. The odd relationship between Doc and Billy grows stranger when Doc hides Billy at his girl Rio’s place after Billy is shot.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: Howard Hughes pushed the boundaries of the code with The Outlaw. Held up for years by the code’s approval process, the film was completed in 1941 yet not widely released until 1946 with the Hays Office taking issue with the sexualisation of Jane Russell and the marketing focus on her chest.

start.title: The Outlaw
start.creator_credit: Howard Hughes, Wallace Grissell, Howard Hughes Productions, RKO Radio Pictures and Jules Furthman
start.brief_description: Newly appointed sheriff Pat Garrett is pleased when his old friend Doc Holliday arrives in Lincoln, New Mexico on the stage. Doc is trailing his stolen horse, and it is discovered in the possession of Billy the Kid. In a surprising turnaround, Billy and Doc become friends. This causes the friendship between Doc and Pat to cool. The odd relationship between Doc and Billy grows stranger when Doc hides Billy at his girl Rio’s place after Billy is shot.

Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

end.title: A Hollywood satire
end.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
end.brief_description: By charting the production process through his surreal images in In Pictures: A Hollywood Satire, photographer Will Connell satirises the absurd overreach of the studios and highlights their control and coercion.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: The kind of focus by filmmakers on women’s bodies and sexuality, like the marketing of The Outlaw, was the kind of thing that Will Connell’s photo series In Pictures: A Hollywood Satire exposed through surreal images.

start.title: From scandal to censorship
start.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
start.brief_description: Concerned that movies promoted loose morals, and scandalised by tabloid stories of stars behaving badly, religious and civic groups lobbied the studios to clean up their act. To avoid government censorship, the industry responded with the Motion Picture Production Code.

Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

end.title: Red-Headed Woman
end.creator_credit: Jack Conway, Adrian, Blanche Sewell, Albert Lewin, Irving Thalberg, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Anita Loos
end.brief_description: Lil works for the Legendre Company and causes Bill to divorce Irene and marry her. She has an affair with businessman Gaerste and uses him to force society to pay attention to her.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: Banned in the UK, pre-code film Red-Headed Woman had it all. A brilliantly clever yet somewhat wicked lead character, comedy and snappy dialogue not to mention premarital sex, attempted murder, marriage breakdown and the original blonde bombshell herself, Jean Harlow.
